words.definition: present, appearing, or found everywhere
words.example: Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society.

words.definition: the occurrence and development of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way
words.example: It was pure serendipity that they met and became best friends.

words.definition: representing the most perfect or typical example of a quality or class
words.example: She is the quintessential professional, always prepared and organised.

words.definition: lasting for a very short time
words.example: The beauty of the cherry blossoms is ephemeral, lasting only a few days.

words.definition: brisk and cheerful readiness
words.example: She accepted the invitation with alacrity, eager to attend the event.

words.definition: a departure from what is normal, usual, or expected, typically an unwelcome one
words.example: The storm was an aberration; the weather had been perfect all week.

words.definition: cease to resist an opponent or an unwelcome demand; surrender
words.example: The soldiers had to capitulate after being surrounded.

words.definition: make (someone) very weak and infirm
words.example: The disease can debilitate even the strongest individuals.

words.definition: make (something) clear; explain
words.example: The professor was able to elucidate the complex theory.

words.definition: having or displaying a passionate intensity
words.example: He was a fervent supporter of the campaign.

words.definition: fond of company; sociable
words.example: She was a gregarious and outgoing person.

words.definition: unfortunate
words.example: The hapless traveller lost his passport on the first day.

words.definition: a person who attacks or criticises cherished beliefs or institutions
words.example: The artist was known as an iconoclast for his controversial works.

words.definition: place or deal with close together for contrasting effect
words.example: The exhibition juxtaposes modern art with classical pieces.

words.definition: (of a person, speech, or style of writing) using very few words
words.example: His laconic reply suggested he was not interested in the conversation.

words.definition: a general feeling of discomfort, illness, or unease whose exact cause is difficult to identify
words.example: A general malaise was apparent among the workers.

words.definition: (typically of an action or activity) wicked or criminal
words.example: The villain's nefarious plot was uncovered by the heroes.

words.definition: render obscure, unclear, or unintelligible
words.example: The politician obfuscated the issue with complex jargon.

words.definition: a person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a particular quality
words.example: She is a paragon of virtue.

words.definition: exceedingly idealistic; unrealistic and impractical
words.example: His quixotic plans were never going to succeed.

words.definition: attractive and impressive through being richly colourful or sumptuous
words.example: The ballroom was resplendent with decorations.

words.definition: a person who acts obsequiously towards someone important in order to gain advantage
words.example: The manager was surrounded by sycophants.

words.definition: (of a person) reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little
words.example: The taciturn man rarely spoke in meetings.

words.definition: present, appearing, or found everywhere
words.example: Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society.

words.definition: wanting or devouring great quantities of food
words.example: He had a voracious appetite after the hike.

words.definition: having or showing zeal
words.example: The volunteers were zealous in their efforts to help the community.

words.definition: make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better
words.example: Measures were taken to ameliorate the situation.

words.definition: well meaning and kindly
words.example: The benevolent woman donated a large sum to charity.

words.definition: having knowledge or being aware of
words.example: He was cognizant of the risks involved.

words.definition: regard or represent as being of little worth
words.example: He never missed an opportunity to disparage his competitors.

words.definition: mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper, especially in a difficult situation
words.example: She accepted the bad news with equanimity.

words.definition: happening by accident or chance rather than design
words.example: Their meeting was entirely fortuitous.

words.definition: pompous or extravagant in language, style, or manner, especially in a way that is intended to impress
words.example: The politician's grandiloquent speech did not impress the audience.

words.definition: a lengthy and aggressive speech
words.example: He delivered a harangue against the government's policies.

words.definition: unable to be upset or excited; calm
words.example: Her imperturbable demeanor helped to calm the nervous crowd.

words.definition: place or deal with close together for contrasting effect
words.example: The artist juxtaposed vibrant colours with dull hues.

words.definition: praise and honour received for an achievement
words.example: She received kudos for her hard work on the project.

words.definition: displaying or having a disinclination for physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed
words.example: The hot weather made them languid and lethargic.

words.definition: a person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society
words.example: The old man was a misanthrope who avoided his neighbours.

words.definition: (of a person or manner) feeling or appearing casually calm and relaxed; not displaying anxiety, interest, or enthusiasm
words.example: She gave a nonchalant shrug when asked about her plans.

words.definition: characterised by vulgar or pretentious display; designed to impress or attract notice
words.example: Her ostentatious jewellery attracted everyone's attention.

words.definition: (of an action or gesture) carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection
words.example: He gave a perfunctory nod and continued with his work.

words.definition: a state of perplexity or uncertainty over what to do in a difficult situation
words.example: She was in a quandary about whether to accept the job offer.

words.definition: having an obstinately uncooperative attitude towards authority or discipline
words.example: The recalcitrant student refused to follow the rules.

words.definition: having or showing keen mental discernment and good judgement; wise or shrewd
words.example: The sagacious leader made decisions that benefitted everyone.

words.definition: understood or implied without being stated
words.example: There was a tacit agreement between the two companies.

words.definition: (of a person) excessively or ingratiatingly flattering; oily
words.example: His unctuous demeanor made everyone distrust him.

words.definition: vehement or clamorous
words.example: The vociferous crowd demanded justice.

words.definition: pass or cause to pass gently through the air
words.example: The smell of freshly baked bread wafted through the air.

words.definition: dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries
words.example: The rise in xenophobia worried many community leaders.

words.definition: have an intense feeling of longing for something, typically something that one has lost or been separated from
words.example: She yearned for the days when they were together.

words.definition: the time at which something is most powerful or successful
words.example: The company reached its zenith in the early 2000s.
